ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of linguistics as well as cognitive science.
Solid understanding of the evolving field of cognitive science and key terminology
I gained so much knowledge about linguistics and insights into some of the reasons why words are spoken the way they are. This course was challenging at times, but also very informative.
Depth in the cognitive science of language

Basic foundation in linguistics. Insight into how to use cognitive science to understand language...and vice versa. 

This was also my first social science course at Yale. Got better at handling various types of academic writing and supporting claims with studies.
Wide base and background in linguistics through the lens of cognitive science, skills in syntactic and phonological analysis as well as in other forms of linguistic thought/practice.
This class helped me correct the misunderstanding that I had that language influences cognition (the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis). I also got a deeper view into the field of linguistics.

We defined what a language is and how human language differs from animal language. We learned about the structures of linguistics including phonology and syntax. We covered language in non-hearing communities, including other topics.
The various theories behind grammatical patterns and how the mind processes language.
I gained a strong understanding about how language transcends something spoken. There was so much I never realized that goes into communication and language and how our brains function.
Course was a bit all oeer the place, but came out with an understanding of how language works in the brain. Pretty good class
I gained new knowledge about cog sci and linguistic topics, as well as how to use some skills in those domains (like making syntax trees)
cogsci of languages

I learned about the cognitive applications of language, and how language does and does not affect our perception. I also learned about how our brains evolved to accommodate this cognitive Load and where else it can be applied.
An introduction to phonology, syntax, cognitive science through language, and a taste of linguistics as a field.
I learned the basic structures and concepts of linguistics, including syntax, morphological structure, sentence structure, and neural networks.
Language and the brain. Interesting stuff!
basic introduction to the cognitive science of language, and the field of linguistics more generally

I learned so much in this class! Though this class is called "cognitive science of language," I definitely learned a lot more about linguistics than about cognitive science. However, material was presented in a clear and interesting manner (even over zoom), making the lectures sufficient for getting a full grasp on course material.
I learned about the arguments for universal grammar as well as phonological and morphological structure.
I learned a lot about basic linguistics and the differences between different languages

I felt this class was really well taught. even though this is not a course for my major, I felt like i still learned alot because of how engaging the lectures were. The professor was always passionate when teaching and helped with my knowledge gained throughout the course. The course materials also helped organize and clarify the topics.

I learned an incredible amount about linguistic analysis in an easy-to-digest format. I have some introductory understanding of phonological and syntactic analysis upon leaving the class, along with some comprehension of both the richness of our linguistic systems and the extent to which language carries deeper cognitive implications.
A good introduction to linguistics from a cognitive perspective.
I learned about phonetics, phonology, linguistics. It was a good introduction to cognitive science from the lens of linguistics.
I learned the basics of linguistics, phonology, grammar, and their relationship to cognition.
I learnt about building blocks of languages and how human's cognition process them
Learned a strong breadth of the foundations of linguistic cognitive science, thought about how the difference between higher cognition and perception can be pinpointed

This class really challenged me to think about human knowledge by questioning how we gain the ability to communicate with one another. By exploring universal grammar through different concepts and studies, I learned more about linguistics.

I learned a lot about the relationship between linguistics and cognitive science. I never realized that our capacity for language had so much to do with the brain, so it was very interesting for me to explore.

Woah. This course was bonkers (in the enthralling/intriguing department). As just one example of what I learned from this course: I think about my own mouth sounds and positions with so much more precision than I did before, and that has enabled me to improve my music production skills as well as understand a little more of what exactly I don't like about hearing my own voice. Moreover, I've been able to be more open-minded and receptive than previously about other people's accents and pronunciations, bettering my ability to accept things I hear as vocally alien.
This course encouraged me to hone and apply various skills ranging from technological comfortability to better use of citations and backup in verbal conversations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was full of fun facts and interesting theories. The lectures were, at times, dense and challenging, but the material covered was generally interesting and engaging. Professor Frank is a very good lecturer, and office hours/review sessions were always helpful. I believe this class could be improved by focusing more on theories of linguistics as opposed to specific phonetics/tableaus. At times, I felt we did not take the time to delve into these topics but were still expected to know the ins and outs of them. I also think this course could be improved if Professor Frank delivered all of the lectures.

Sometimes I felt the course went a little too deep into the material for a course that should be introductory. The 4 homeworks were also somewhat long, which was not an issue for me but could clash with your schedule. The tests were fine, though.
No particular weaknesses come to mind.
The course was very very broad yet still very deep, which made it rather difficult at times.

Strengths - very useful overlap between lectures and readings. Good preparation for exams. 

Weaknesses - sometimes homework instructions weren't clear.

Strengths:
- extremely well organized material
- lectures made easy to understand and follow by instructors and TA's

Weaknesses:
- pacing of content could be improved
- having a final exam during the exam period as well as a final project seemed a bit much in terms of workload

Overall, the course is great.

Less scientific articles or reading studies might be good, but finding material that synthesizes findings might not always be possible.

Strengths - Professor Frank is very good at explaining material -- you can tell he's supposed to be a professor. The readings were long and dense and had lots of technical jargon, but you didn't even have to do the readings (I stopped after a few weeks of trying) because Professor Frank explained them so well in class. The PowerPoints were helpful for review, and the exams were pretty fair.
Weaknesses - The assignments. They weren't on the syllabus, so we were given a week's heads up (not enough time for planning when all other classes has their assignments posted on the syllabus). They kind of just dropped out of thin air, and towards the middle/end of the semester, we'd have assignment after assignment with no breaks in between. It would have been better if they were more spread out. They were also SUPER hard to understand and EXTREMELY time consuming.

The course was well-taught and there were many opportunities to ask questions in class and in office hours. The material was very engaging and I loved how the material was presented in a way in which we could "discover" with the professor if experiments provided accurate results or if results needed further rebuttal to be countered.

Strengths: The material was interesting.

Weaknesses: The homework had vague instructions. Also, there was a lot of application questions, which was a skill that wasn't necessarily taught.
I thought that the course was well-organized and the topics discussed were interesting. Based on personal preference though, there were some topics that were not as interesting as others.

Strengths are the material - super interesting. Professor Frank is also very kind and helpful
Weaknesses - homework and exams. Did not really reflect what we learned. The material in class was covered quickly always, the homework was sometimes very abstract and we didn't receive clear feedback. When we got to the exam, it didn't really reflect what the material was about and felt underprepared for it

This course NEEDS to have an organized schedule of when assignments are assigned and due because the professor just throws them out at random times giving us no chance to plan around our other assignments.

The only weakness was that some of the homework assignments took much longer than expected. But overall, the material was interesting, the lectures were engaging, and the expectations were clear and reasonable.
Bob Frank is the biggest strength of this class, he makes learning fun!
a huge downside is the fact that it was very technical, and there was little big picture take aways. exams were also very vague and graded harshly.

The course was extremely engaging, lecture wise. The material was presented incrementally and intuitively, and I almost never felt lost or confused. I think some lectures dragged on a little more than others, but overall it was interesting.

Well structured and taught. Strengths: exams felt like the perfect difficulty. They were relevant to course material and the readings, and sometimes required inference/extra thinking. Weaknesses: a few lectures felt slow and hard to follow, especially with the class as 75 minutes. Most lectures were well paced and stayed engaging though.

The lectures were clear and interesting, as were the expectations for reading responses and the exams. The homework problems were a bit more sporadic, and we didn't really know when they would be assigned or how much time they would take. In general, they were quite confusing (in their wording), but were interesting once you understood what was being asked.

I feel that the content of the course is misrepresented. As a cognitive science major, I often found myself missing cognitive science related content. I think the teaching team spent a lot of time building a foundation in the general linguistics topics like phonetics and structure and grammar, but not a lot of time on bigger cognitive science topics like acquisition and nativism. I think the class would have been more enjoyable had it centered more typically cognitive science related topics.

Strengths: really interesting concepts, and I liked the casual but fun nature of the final essay project as a blog post! The reading responses were fairly easy to complete, and the TA team was very quick to respond to emails. Weaknesses: some concepts were hard to understand even on recorded lecture when I could go back, so I can't imagine how it would be in-person or live lecture when you can't pause and process the material. Syntax lecture unit was extremely difficult to understand, and it was hard to know what was going to be tested since there was so much extraneous material on it. The homework assignments were also hard to answer, so much so that I almost dropped the class before one was due because it seemed so impossible to complete. Luckily, I continued through once Prof Frank started teaching again, and I'm glad I stuck with it. Review sessions were also really early, so I couldn't make most of them.
Its a lot of fun and the course is neatly organized. Cant really think of weaknesses.
Strenghts: there were always resources for help and TA's to meet with. The class was very organized and slides were always concise.

Strengths - great introduction to cognitive science of language, a lot of material covered
Weaknesses - sometimes the lectures were a bit hard to follow, a lot of jargon used. Can be improved by making lectures more engaging

Problem sets (called homeworks) should have been assigned earlier. We generally found out about a week before a problem set 2 that it existed and had about 5-7 days to complete the whole assignment, with little understanding of which weeks they'd be assigned. As someone who falls behind (a lot) on recorded lectures when there is no looming deadline, I found myself binge-watching lectures until 3 am the weeks we had homework assignments (yes, my fault, but a heads up would have been nice). Otherwise, the course was well organized and engaging! Exams were fair.

This course's main strength is the passion that Professor Frank has for the material. Despite this, it has some serious weaknesses - many of the assignments are bizarrely difficult and require skills that are not taught in class. The course is a review course, but the exams focused on minor areas that weren't given prominence in the lectures. To improve this class I think the Professor either needs to make it a class focused on acquiring deeper knowledge of fewer areas, or design exams for a review course.
I would have liked the study guide for the midterm and final to be given to us at the beginning of the semester, it very clearly outline important topics we should look out for.
Very hard to understand
The PSETs were too hard compared to what we learned in class. Also, too much linguistics focus when it shouldve been more cogsci.
The strength of this course was the lectures and the setup of exams/homeworks. Weakness was the times available for office hours, as it was hard to make them given other course schedules

Strengths: engaging professor, interesting material, helpful and understanding teaching team (they respond to emails really fast, and do it thoughtfully)
Weakness: the syllabus wasn't up to date which made it hard to plan ahead sometimes
The major weakness was how detailed and time-consuming the homeworks were. The phonology part of the course was very dry sometimes. Lastly, the syllabus was not very helpful.
This course was very informative and covered a broad range of topics. Lectures were quite one-sided, however, and could have benefited from more interaction with students.
This course was taught beautifully. Professor Frank is an amazing lecturer and he always make materials that are difficult and new to be become digestible with great slides and examples.

Weaknesses: lectures can lose you real quick and then you never catch up until you rewatch it on recording, the homeworks were few but were very tedious and annoying which caused unnecessary stress, the final exam and project felt a bit crammed at the end of the semester
Strengths: professor is very kind and helpful when he's available
The reading responses and homeworks were really helpful in clarifying and applying the content from lecture.

Strength: Very interesting intro class for anyone who is curious about linguistics or about human cognition. A great social science credit for non-social science majors.
Weakness: At some points the materials get a little confusing. This is partly because the studies/experiments we learn about don't always have conclusive results, so sometimes I found myself wondering what exactly I should take away from the various case studies. But this is probably just because we still don't know enough about our cognitive system.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought it went great!
Not much was done

Having a large number of assignments to periodically practice writing and expression of content helped practice for exams. Recordings of lectures and recordings/existence of review sessions helped prepare for the exams for the course.

Having one assignment available to redo and get back half credit was helpful because a) it helped your grade b) redoing the assignment forced you to understand the material. 

The open note exams were a very good move because I could not have imagined having to do that exam without my notes -- there was so much information, but since I knew the exam would be open note, my notes were fantastic because I actually tried to take good notes!

The reading responses being graded on completion helped with not being overly stressed about them.
I like how lectures can be recorded. I attended them all live, but it was nice to have something to reference to when I couldn't remember something/needed to review the explanation again.
Appreciated the flexibility in exam taking and time periods. Helped a lot
The chat feature in zoom was frequently utilized to allow for quick feedback from students.
Homework was a bit confusing
Online homework submission was easy and accommodating. Our professor gave us ample room to ensure that we were doing well, and the exams were also accessible and felt fair.

Recorded lectures were amazing and really helped me to solidify material especially before exams. Open note exams helped me to understand the concept rather than memorize it, and short answer format helped to test that I truly understood it rather than just copied a definition. 24hour window also helped give flexibility, especially during finals period!

Succeeded - the homework assignments and exams were well structured and adapted to the pandemic
Improved - the lectures were 1 hour 15 minutes with little to no engagement, so sometimes it was hard to stay focused the entire time

The lecture was recorded. Only way to make the class more engaging would probably be to avoid recording lectures to force students to attend instead of putting them off. However, being able to rewatch certain lecture sections when studying for an exam is extremely beneficial, so I wouldn't change this structure.
This class by far did the worst job of handling the unconventionality of this Zoom semester and it is not even close. Even the final exam had its share of technological difficulties.
I liked the setup of live virtual lecture, as well as having the lecture recorded so that we could go back and rewatch (very helpful when studying).
Having the lectures recorded were helpful for later review.

The virtual live lecture format was successful in my opinion, and I especially appreciated that they were recorded for later review. Office hours were often at very early times, and more afternoon or evening sessions would have been helpful.
The recorded lecture is always provided quickly. It is also really quick to get a response from the course staff email.
I absolutely depended on the recorded lectures in order to understand the material and rewatch explanations, they were highly appreciated and essential

While Professor Frank asked if we needed anything in lecture to be clarified, I think it was hard for us to speak up. Having polls, surveys included in lecture would have been helpful to interact with the material. Or having a form to submit some type of feedback.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes!
Yes! If you are at all curious about linguistics, this is a fun class to take. The assignments, particularly the final project, are also enjoyable

Yes, this was the first cognitive science course I took at Yale and it gave me a new perspective on things. Though the workload is on the lower side, I would not call it a gut, as you still have to put in the work to understand the topics and how they all fit together.

I think the content of this course is somewhat different from what I expected going in, but nonetheless really informative and educational. I would recommend this course to students who are truly interested in both cognitive science and linguistics, but maybe not if they are only interested in cognitive science.
Not unless you are already REALLY interested and knowledgeable about linguistics. About half the course went over my head as someone with just psyc/cogsci exposure.
Yes. This course is really, really interesting. Changed how I think about language.

I would recommend this course to a student who is motivated to learn about intricate processes that occur within the mind that help us understand and formulate language. If you are bilingual, that could be a strength or a weakness depending on if you switch between languages often.

No, I would not recommend this course to another student unless you know that you like/you'll like linguistics. I took this class as a potential cognitive science major, and I'm leaving the class with serious doubts on whether that's the major for me because I really did not enjoy it. I'm not sure if other people enjoyed it but for me personally I did not enjoy it and would not recommend unless linguistics is your thing. there was a lot of really technical information and the homework assignments were also very technical and complex and hard to understand. and do not be deceived by the first week of the material of the course. that stuff was actually pretty interesting, but once we got further into the course it became more linguistics heavy rather than cognitive science heavy. I do hear that this course is not representative of the other courses in the major though.
I would recommend the course. The course material was interesting and provided insight for those who are language enthusiasts or interested in cognitive science.
No, probably not.
If the student was interested in the nuances and intricacies of all things language then yes.

Overall yes. Bob frank is very kind and a good professor, there is interest information. Definitely take it if youre interested in Cog Sci / linguistics / psych. It's still a good intro class even if youre not sure what youre interested in, but mostly helps students in these areas
I would only recommend this course if you are willing to take on the erratic workload and also see TAs about the homeworks because you will be lost without help.
Yes, if they're interested in cognitive science. Prof. Frank is an excellent lecturer, and this is the perfect intro course to both cognitive science and linguistics.
no, it wasnt a fun course
Yes
I would recommend this to another student as it is interesting and accessible. The material is a great segway into other cognitive science topics.
Highly recommend to anyone interested in learning more about how language works in our brain. Professor Frank is an amazing lecturer!
I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in linguistics or cognitive science, or even to someone with a passing interest in the topics.

I would recommend this course to someone if they already know they are interested in linguistics. The first lecture was an inspiring introduction to the field, but the majority of the course was spent studying nitty gritty topics like phonology and grammatical categories. If grammar trees and tables about syllable structure seem enjoyable to you, it will be a worthwhile experience. If you're taking it as a gut, you will probably find yourself needing to spend a lot more time on these topics than you might have hoped. Still, it would be a very interesting experience.
I would only recommend this close to (prospective) Linguistics majors or Cognitive Science majors with a linguistics related depth theme.

If you are interesting in linguistics or NLP, yes!! The last unit on neural networks and context-free grammar gave me a lightbulb moment which reaffirmed my passion for linguistics. The concepts of grammar and syntax were also really interesting just for general knowledge! As a cogsci major, it was amazing.
yes!
I would recommend this course to another student (especially if it's for a pre-requisite) since it gives a good introduction to many different topics in linguistics
Yes! The course is a great introduction to linguistic thinking as well as aspects of language acquisition and development. If any of these topics sound interesting, this is a great class for you!

Although I really enjoyed the material, I'm not sure I would recommend this class. The assignments were complicated, long, and required skills we were not directly taught in class. The exams were overly specific and challenging. However, the content and Professor are great.
Only if they are up for a supreme challenge
I would absolutely not unless you have a strong desire to learn about linguistics. Even in that case, Id still caution against it.
Its ok. You will need a lot of help with PSETS

If you are looking for an interesting class to take, even if you arent this major, I would take it! you do have to be engaged in order to understand the material, but if you do the class is straightforward and fun!

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone with even a passing interest in linguistics. The course offers a wonderfully comprehensive look into several key linguistic principles and does a fantastic job making them accessible and engaging. I would also easily recommend the course to potential Cognitive Science majors with any interest at all in language or, to a lesser extent, cultural psychology.
Yes! If you're interested in cognitive science of language, Prof Frank is a great professor and he makes the topics very accessible!

If you are not interested in phonetics or phonology, this course can be too boring at times. However, most of the topics were very interesting to learn about, such as the effects of language on perception, theory of mind and language, etc.

Yes, especially if you want to get a working knowledge of what language really is and what its components are. A really interesting feature of this class was putting names to things I did subconsciously while speaking English!
Definitely take it if you are whatsoever interested in language or cognition. I came in blind and I learn so many things!

I would not overall, as a cog sci major I am just glad it's over. Course material is interesting, however the few but tedious homework assignments gave me too much stress for no reason. I spent a full 2 hours of TA office hours on the last homework just to end up right where I started (except exponentially more frustrated) since I received a bunch of "if I answer that, it will be too much of a give-away" even though I had literally no idea how to understand the problem that we were working on. This class was much better when recorded since you could rewind and repeat if you missed something (which was often for me). I ended up just tapping out of live lectures since I got lost easily and watched the recordings later on. Exams are ehhhh and the project actually wasn't bad if you liked your topic. BUT, having a big final project due during reading period and then an exam the following week got me stressing a lot on top of my other classes. It was a little too easy to forget about this class due to the sporadic-ness of assignments and such. If you want an intro linguistics or cog sci class, please go elsewhere. This class was rough for me even as an experienced cog sci major. This is the only class I regretted taking this semester.
Yes! It's a great intro course for anyone interested in human brain or linguistics. Also a great choice for anyone who just needs a social science credit.
I don't think I couldn't recommend this course. It was a fun, fascinating foray into humans and their speech.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also a live lecture, but I watched the recorded lectures asynchronously due to a course conflict.
Lectures were recorded
Live virtual lectures were recorded and placed on Media Library
None
Lectures were also recorded
n/a
I also utilized the recorded versions of the lectures because I had a class that overlapped with the live time slot.
the class was also recorded
Live virtual lecture (which was also recorded).
canvas assignments
Watched recorded lectures
Each lecture occurred synchronously, but all the lectures were available as recordings for students in different timezones or with timing conflicts.
Lectures were also recorded.
The class was a live virtual lecture, but all of the classes were recorded so students had the option to participate asynchronously.
NA
Lectures were also recorded.
n/a
there were also office hours throughout the week
live lecture which was recorded for later viewing
live virtual lectures, which were recorded
I also watched recorded lectures.
Recorded live virtual lectures.
recorded lecture
Live virtual lectures which are recorded to allow for asynchronous attendance.
